messageBody:
hyysguyang wrote:
>
>
> Hello,
> Here is my practice about TDD in my daily life , But I dont know if
> I make any mistakes, so could you please tell me how to practice TDD
> in your daily work?Any suggestions or recommendations will be most
> appreciated.
> Below is one real world practice in my TDD practice:
> Requirement: Reverse the setence 'TDD is a software devolopment
> technology' to 'technology devolopment software a is TDD'.
> Attention please, this is all requirement.
>
> I started my coding by following below instruction:
> 1. Quickly add a test.
> 2. Run all tests and see the new one fail.
> 3. Make a little change.
> 4. Run all tests and see them all succeed.
> 5. Refactor to remove duplication.
>
> First step I write a test case to describe the requirement.
>
> package org.opensource.test;
> import org.junit.Assert;
> import org.junit.Test;
> public class StringReverseTest {
> @Test
> public void testReverse(){
> StringReverser sr=new StringReverser();
> String str = "Tdd is a software devolopment technology";
> Assert.assertEquals("technology devolopment software a is
> Tdd",sr.reverse(str));
> }
> }

What if you started with a simpler test?

@Test public void emptyString() {
Assert.assertEquals("", reverse(""));
}

The next test would be a one-word sentence, then a three-word sentence.
This approach might help you avoid thinking about multiple details at once.
